subject: Safe db.api.compute_node_get_all() performance improvement
commit_message:
Safe db.api.compute_node_get_all() performance improvement

Scheduler stores the essential information for its work in DB in 3
tables: 'services', 'compute_nodes' and 'compute_node_stats'. For
each compute node, there is 1 record in 'services', 1 record in
'compute_nodes' and about 10 records in 'compute_node_stats'.

Each user request to scheduler to schedule an instance results
in a call to the db.api.compute_node_get_all() method which fetches
the information about all the compute nodes, their services and
corresponding stats in a single list.

There were 2 problems with the previous implementation of this
method. The first one was connected with network traffic: the
use of JOIN operation resulted in redundant informaion
returned from the DB in the resulting denormalized table. The
second one was a performance problem in the SQLAlchemy ORM's
implementation of data processing (slow model mappings in JOINs).

As we are just returning all the data from these 3 tables, we
have implemented a lower-level approach to solve these problems:
to reduce the network traffic, the new implementation of this
method fetches all the necessary data from 3 tables separately,
querying only for those columns that will be actually needed by
the scheduler ('created_at', 'deleted_at', 'updated_at' and
'deleted' columns get removed if the 'no_date_fields' parameter is
set to True). It then joins these tables manually, which allows
to avoid using the slow SQLAlchemy ORM's model mapping and thus
enables to speed up the whole process significantly.

We have tested the new implementation against the old one (with
the 'no_date_fields' parameter set to True). In our test example,
we have 10k services, 10k compute_nodes and 100k records in the
compute_node_stats (each key and each value is 15 characters in
length) database. The results are as follows:

+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| Approach                              | Time      | Traffic | Python memory |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| ORM joinedload (all columns)          | 15.58 sec | 26.8 MB | 579.9 MB      |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| ORM joinedload (filtered columns)     | n/a       | 17.2 MB | n/a           |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| core + manual join (all columns)      | 7.67 sec  | 9.4 MB  | 223.6 MB      |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| core + manual join (filtered columns) | 5.15 sec  | 5.6 MB  | 112.5 MB      |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+

So our new implementation has 3 times better performance, uses 5 times
less traffic and yields 5 times less memory usage than the old one.

Test data was edited slightly here to reflect the real-world system
behaviour (services corresponding to compute nodes come with
binary='nova-compute').

Change-Id: Ie5ef00c974b810336787e88c78c93c15ca2890d3
Partial-Bug: #1212428

This fixes the lock path for storage-registry-lock to prevent a
potential data loss due to a race-condition scenario.  Since the
storage-registry-lock is used to modify a json blob that is
authoritative as to which nodes are using the storage so that
we don't remove any "in-use" backing files on the shared storage
segment (if in use).

The potential data-loss could occur in limited cases of the race
that the lock should prevent.  This can only occur if the image
cache cleanup is triggerd when a node has been eliminated from
the register_storage_use JSON incorrectly by this race condition.

subject: Race condition during init_host
commit_message:
Race condition during init_host

Solves race condition that potentially can lead to multiple instances
running from same disk on different hosts.
When compute service starts it checks whether managed instances
been evacuated to another host (in
manager._destroy_evacuated_instances). The time between this check and
when service appears to be active via servicegroup is a time when
instance can be evacuated to another host which will lead to duplicated
instances in the environment.

This patch solves it by keeping all the instances task_state in
"initing" until service initialization finished. In this way
evacuation of those instances can't be started.

subject: fix(mongodb): Marker generation creates a bottleneck under heavy load
commit_message:
fix(mongodb): Marker generation creates a bottleneck under heavy load

This patch changes markers so that they are generated using a per-queue
side counter. A heuristic is used to mitigate a race condition. Due to the
new semantics, partial inserts are no longer possible due to collisions,
which ended up simplifying the retry logic for posting messages.

As a consequence of this patch, the last message posted no longer needs
to remain in the queue indefinitely, rendering marconi-gc unnecessary,
and so it has been removed.

Also, since the mongod GC worker runs once a minute, the queries no longer
filter out expired-but-not-yet-gc'd messages; on average, a message may
live more than 30 seconds passed it's expected lifetime, but I do not
think that this will harm or complicate any application building on top of
Marconi, practically speaking. That being said, it is worth calling out
in documentation.

Closes-Bug: #1218602

subject: Fix subparsers add_parser() regression
commit_message:
Fix subparsers add_parser() regression

With SubCommandOpt, the handler() callback gets invoked with a
subparsers object which has a add_parser() method. The arguments to
this method match the arguments to the ArgumentParser constructor and
the arguments are passed to the class for our ArgumentParser instance.

However, we added a ArgumentParser subclass (_CachedArgumentParser) so
that we could sort the output of --help ... but the subclass doesn't
support all the arguments of the parent class.

glance-control is the only known example of a SubCommandOpt user which
passes unusual arguments to subparsers.add_parser(). It uses the parent
arg and blows up at startup with:

   File "./bin/glance-control", line 276, in add_command_parsers
     parser = subparsers.add_parser(server, parents=[cmd_parser])
   File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/argparse.py", line 1064, in add_parser
     parser = self._parser_class(**kwargs)
 TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'parents'

It appears we broke glance-control back in June (commit 2951391), but
nobody noticed it until 1.2.0 was released and broke stable/grizzly
because we stopped using glance-control in the Havana glance unit tests
before this regression.

Closes-Bug: #1230416

Functional test suite for devtest.

This commit adds a test suite that can be run against the OpenStack
environments that are set up by devtest.  There are tests for the

HOT str_replace to use string.replace, not string.Template

str_replace uses python templates, whereas Fn::Replace uses python
string.replace.

During the original review for Fn::Replace, python templates were
decided against because $ would often need double-escaping in shell scripts.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/31736/

Having different behaviours between Fn::Replace and str_replace will
add complication for users migrating existing templates to HOT.

Another advantage of using straight string replacement is seen when
the template generates a executable script. In this case it is generally
possible to write a template that can also be executed directly in a
dev/test environment. This would often not be possible if the template
format required placeholders to be prefixed with a $.

Whatever behaviour exists when Havana is release will have to be
supported indefinitely so now is the time to decide if this is going
to be fixed.

subject: disassociate_address response should match ec2
commit_message: disassociate_address response should match ec2 The current behavior of disassociate_address does not match that of what EC2 would return when calling it upon an unassociated address. In EC2 when disassociate_address is called on an unassociated address, it returns successfully as such: aabbccdd-0146-4952-bdbe-710e4fee8387 true However, when this same called is made against the OpenStack EC2 implementation, this would return a 400: InvalidInstanceID.NotFound Instance None could not be found. req-7a9b4d03-b9f5-4243-95d8-f1ccab180631 This is due to the fact that we continue to attempt disassociation despite instance_id == None. Modify this behavior to match EC2 by simply checking that instance_id is set before continuing disassociation. Else, bail early, and in either case report success. This change also modifies unit tests to account for this change. Change-Id: I17c822d70918fefa55da2ab096af5b98b87e23e7 Closes-Bug: #1224251
